title: 113_hr868
content:
The "Safer Neighborhoods Gun Buyback Act of 2013" authorizes the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance to provide grants to eligible entities for conducting gun buyback programs. Eligible entities include states, local governments, and gun dealers in areas where neither the state nor local government receives a grant. SEC. 3. APPLICATIONS.

Eligible entities must submit grant applications to the Director, while gun dealers in areas without grants must apply for subgrants from their local government or State. Proof of dealer's license is required.

SEC. 4. TERM OF GRANT. The term of a grant awarded under this Act is two years. Gun dealers must return any remaining smart prepaid cards and unused grant funds allocated for gun buybacks at the end of the two-year period. States or units of local government must also adhere to the grant terms. States or local governments receiving a grant under this Act must return any unused funds to the Director after a two-year period. The Director will then return these funds to the Treasury's general fund. SEC. 5. SMART PREPAID CARDS. The Director may reserve funds to distribute smart prepaid cards to eligible entities without loaded funds. Market value of guns listed in section 7(2) will be determined and made public. Prohibition on using cards to buy guns or ammunition, with penalties for violations. SEC. 6. USES OF FUNDS. States and Units of Local Government receiving grants under this Act must use the funds to distribute 80% as subgrants to gun dealers for buyback programs, distribute smart prepaid cards, and allocate 10% for recycling guns into various steel products. Gun dealers receiving grants under this Act must use the funds for gun buyback programs, loading 125% of the market value of the gun onto a smart prepaid card. The administrative costs of the grant program should not exceed 10%. Gun dealers must load an amount onto a smart prepaid card greater than 125% of the market value of altered guns received under the buyback program. Guns must be delivered to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives within 60 days. Gun dealers participating in the gun buyback program must deliver guns received under the program to the State or local government within 60 days. Grant funds can be used to provide incentives to gun dealers to encourage participation in the program. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "gun" is defined as a "firearm" as per section 921(a)(3) of title 18, United States Code. The term "gun buyback program" refers to a program where a gun dealer purchases specific guns from individuals using smart prepaid cards. The curr_chunk discusses various types of firearms, including Smith and Wesson pistols and Bryco Arms pistols. It also defines the term "gun dealer" as a licensed dealer of firearms. Additionally, it defines a "smart prepaid card" as a card that can be redeemed at multiple merchants but has mechanisms to prevent the purchase of guns or ammunition. The curr_chunk discusses the use of a smart prepaid card that prohibits purchases at gun stores and pawn shops, can be loaded by a gun dealer for buyback programs, and must bear a specific warning message. The term "State" is defined as each of the 50 States and the District of Columbia. Authorization of $360,000,000 for fiscal years 2014-2016 for Act implementation.
